title: Production and characterization of cell-penetrating recombinant botulinum neurotoxin type A
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Production of recombinant CPP-BoNTA proteins
Timing: 21 days
This section describes how recombinant CPP-BoNTA proteins are produced. There are three major steps, including plasmid construction (4 days), protein expression (15 days) and protein purification (2 days).
Plasmid construction
Timing: 4 days (for step 1)
This section describes how to construct recombinant plasmids encoding CPP-BoNTA proteins. Plasmid construction follows the general molecular cloning procedures and includes 6 sequential steps: PCR reaction, restriction digestion, gel extraction of digestion products, ligation, transformation and bacterial cultivation and DNA purification.
PCR Reaction.
Set up the PCR reaction using an insect cell codon-optimized synthesized BoNTA gene (GENEWIZ).
Note: The forward primers for BoNTA, T-BoNTA and Z-BoNTA (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) all contain N-terminal FLAG and His6 tags (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A). The PCR primers introduce 5′-XbaI and 3′-HindIII restriction sites for cloning into pFastBac1 vector (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Design of CPP-BoNTA fusion proteins
(A) Architecture of BoNTA proteins. The PCR amplicons of BoNTA, T-BoNTA and Z-BoNTA are generated using synthesized BoNTA as the template and different pairs of primers.
(B) Plasmid map of BoNTA-harboring pFastBac1 plasmid. The cloning sites for gene insertion is indicated.
Set up PCR reactions in 8-tube strips.
Note: Master mix (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section) should be prepared for 1.2× the number of samples to account for the loss during pipetting process.
Set up the PCR reaction as follows:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2356_11.csv
Collect the PCR product (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A) using MinElute PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen). Elute the DNA using 10 μL of water. Store at −20°C for one week.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Gel image of PCR products before and after digestion and digested vector
(A) PCR product (Marker, Trans2K Plus Marker). The images are collected from separate agarose gels.
(B) Digested pFastBac1 vector (Marker, Trans2K Plus Marker).
Restriction digestion.

Digest pFastBac1 vector and PCR products with XbaI and HindIII (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Set up digestion in 8-tube strips. Prepare master mix according to the table in the materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section.
Incubate the reaction at 37°C for 3 h, and then add calf intestinal alkaline phosphatase (CIP) of 0.5 μL for further incubation for 30 min.
Gel Extraction of digested pFastBac1 vector and PCR amplicon.
Mix the digestion products from step 2 with 10 μL of 6× DNA loading dye.
Prepare 1% (wt/vol) agarose gel with Tris acetate-EDTA (TAE) buffer.
Run the gel at 100 volts (V) for 45 min.
Cut the desired band from the agarose gel, and dissolve it in one volume binding buffer (XP2) for 7 min at 60°C.
Run the solubilized gel through a HiBind DNA Mini Column from the Omega Gel Extraction Kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://www.omegabiotek.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/D2500.D2501-Gel-Extraction-Kit-Combo-Online.pdf], and elute DNA using 20 μL of water.
Store the purified digestion products (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A and 2B) at −20°C for one week.
Ligation.
Ligate the enzyme-treated PCR product and pFastBac1 vector from step 3.
Set up an insert-to-vector molar ratio of 3:1. Master mix can be prepared according to the table in the materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section.
Incubate the reaction at 16°C for 12–16 h.
Transformation.
Thaw 100 μL of Trelief 5α Chemically Competent Cell on ice, and mix them gently with 10 μL of the ligation reaction product from step 4.
Keep the cells on ice for 15 min.
Heat-shock the mixture at 42°C for 90 s using a water bath followed by incubation on ice for 3 min.
Transfer the cell suspension to a culture tube containing 0.5 mL of LB medium.
Incubate the cells with shaking at 200 g for 1 h at 37°C.

Spread 200 μL of the bacterial cell culture on an LB agar plates with 50 μg/mL kanamycin and incubate the plates at 37°C for 12–16 h.
Bacterial cultivation and DNA purification.
Prepare growth medium (LB medium containing 50 μg/mL kanamycin). Add 5 mL of growth medium in 14 mL round bottom test tubes.
Inoculate each tube with a single colony from a successful transformation.
Grow bacterial culture for 12–16 h in a 37°C incubator with a shaking platform set to 225 rpm.
Collect the bacteria by centrifugation at 5000 g for 10 min.
Extract the plasmid harboring the gene of interest using the Qiagen plasmid miniprep kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/dna-rna-purification/dna-purification/plasmid-dna/qiagen-plasmid-kits?catno=12123], and confirm plasmid identity by DNA sequencing.
Store at −20°C for long-term use.
Protein expression
Timing: 15 days (for step 7)
This section describes the expression of recombinant CPP-BoNTA proteins. The expression process in insect cells relies on BEVS and consists of 5 sequential steps: transposition, bacmid isolation, transfection of bacmid into Sf9 cells, viral amplification and protein expression.
Transposition.
Prepare LB agar plates containing 50 μg/mL kanamycin, 7 μg/mL gentamicin, 10 μg/mL tetracycline, 100–300 μg/mL Blue-gal and 40 μg/mL IPTG.
Thaw the DH10BacY competent cells on ice.
Dispense 100 μL of the cells into 1.5 mL tubes.
Add approximately 1 μg recombinant donor plasmid (in 5 μL ddH2O) and gently mix the DNA into the cells by tapping the side of the tube.
Incubate the mixture on ice for 30 min.
Heat shock the mixture at 42°C water bath for 45 s.
Chill the mixture on ice for 2 min.
Add 500 μL LB to the mixture.
Place the mixture in a shaking incubator at 37°C with a shaking speed of 225 rpm for 4 h.
Dilute 20 μL transposition mixture with 100 μL LB.

Place 120 μL of each dilution on the plates and spread evenly over the surface.
Incubate for 24–48 h at 37°C.
Note: Blue colonies may not be discernible at the first 24 h due to the small size.
Pick white single colony and inoculate into 5 mL LB medium supplemented with 50 μg/mL kanamycin, 7 μg/mL gentamicin and 10 μg/mL tetracycline in 14 mL round bottom test tubes.
Grow at 37°C to stationary phase (16–24 h) with shaking at 250–300 rpm.
Bacmid preparation.
For each expression construct, pick up two white colonies for bacmid isolation.
Harvest cells and resuspend cell pellet with 250 μL Buffer P1 from the Qiagen Plasmid Mini Kit and transfer the resuspension into a transparent 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Lyse the cells with 250 μL Buffer P2 followed by neutralization using 350 μL of Buffer N3.
After neutralization, spin at around 16,000 g for 10 min at 4°C.
Critical: Due to the involvement of ethanol during the bacmid extraction, the test tubes should be labeled with ethanol-resistant markers.
After centrifugation, transfer the supernatant (∼800 μL) to a transparent 1.5 mL tube by careful pipetting.
Spin the supernatant at 16,000 g for 3 min at 4°C.
Note: This step helps to remove the remaining cell debris, which might decrease the transfection efficiency.
After centrifugation, transfer the supernatant (∼720 μL) to a transparent 1.5 mL tube by careful pipetting. Add 500 μL isopropanol and thoroughly mix the solution.
Spin the mixture for 10 min at 16,000 g at 4°C.
Critical: During this step, set up the transfection experiment in advance by switching on the UV light of the cabinet in the insect cell facility and warming up FuGENE transfection agent (E2311, Promega) to 20°C.
Remove the supernatant by pipetting carefully.

Note: A small whitish pellet containing the DNA might be visible at the bottom of the tube.
Add 200 μL cold 70% ethanol to wash the pellet. Spin for 5 min at 16,000 g at 4°C.
After centrifugation, remove the supernatant by pipetting carefully with a 200 μL tip, and then gently add 50 μL cold 70% ethanol.
Critical: The 70% ethanol can keep the DNA pellet and test tubes sterile. Avoid disturbance of the DNA pellet at the bottom of the test tubes when 70% ethanol is added.
Bring the closed tubes containing the bacmids in 70% ethanol into a sterile laminar flow cabinet.
Remove the 50 μL 70% ethanol by pipetting carefully. Air-dry the pellets for 10 min.
Critical: Make sure sterile environment is maintained during this step. Make sure ethanol is completely removed. Residual ethanol in the bacmid samples may affect transfection efficiency and cell viability.
Add 30 μL of sterile water to each tube. Resuspend DNA pellets by tapping gently.
Critical: Due to the large size, improper resuspension may cause damage to bacmids due to shearing force.
Transfection of bacmid into Sf9 cells.
Seed 0.5–1.0 × 106 insect cells into a 6-well plate and incubate at 27°C for 15 min before transfection.
Note: The 15 min incubation allows the cells to settle.
Prepare the following solution in the sterile cabinet for bacmid transfection:
Solution A: add 10 μL FuGENE transfection agent into 100 μL Sf-900 II serum-free medium.
Solution B: add 25 μL bacmid into 200 μL Sf-900 II serum-free medium.
Mix solution A and solution B and incubate at 25°C for 15–30 min.
Added mixed solution A-B into seeded Sf9 culture drop by drop.

Note: The two bacmid preparations from two separate single colonies as described in step 8 are used in transfection to ensure the success of BV production. Each bacmid has two transfection replicates and a non-transfected group is also included. This corresponds to five transfection group on the plate, including bacmid1, bacmid1’ (replicate), bacmid2, bacmid2’ (replicate) and a control group.
Critical: The final medium volume after transfection should be 2.5–3.0 mL.
After transfection, swirl the 6-well plate gently to ensure even distribution of the cells.
Incubate the transfected 6-well plates at 27°C in the dark. Check the cells every day for contamination and viability.
Note: Successfully transfected cells typically exhibit enlarged size in morphology. The majority of the cells will be infected at the third day post transfection.
Collect the medium supernatant at 72 h after incubation.
Centrifuge the medium supernatant at 1,000 g for 10 min at 4°C to remove cell debris.
Harvest the supernatant as initial virus (P1). Store at 4°C in dark for immediate use or at −20°C in dark for long-term use.
Note: Baculovirus is regarded as biosafety level 1 (BSL-1) reagent by authority. However, due to the replicative nature of baculovirus in insect cells, it is preferred to handle baculovirus in virus-specialized cabinet to prevent potential cross contamination.
Viral amplification.
Seed insect cells with viability of more than 95% into 125 mL shake flasks containing Sf-900 II serum-free medium at a density of 1–1.5 × 106/mL.
Add 2 mL P1 viral stock to suspension Sf9 cells.
Incubate the cells in a 27°C incubator with a stirring rate of 120 rpm.
At 72 h post-infection, count and record cell density and viability.
Collect the medium containing virus (P2) from shaker flasks.

Centrifuge the virus-containing medium at 500 g for 5 min at 4°C to remove cells and large debris. Store at 4°C in dark for immediate use or at −20°C in dark for long-term use.
Seed insect cells with viability of more than 95% into 250 mL shake flasks containing Sf-900 II serum-free medium at a density of 1–1.5 × 106 cells/mL.
Add P2 viral stock (1% v/v) to suspension Sf9 cells.
Incubate the cells in a 27°C incubator with a stirring rate of 120 rpm.
At 72 h post-infection, count and record cell density and viability.
Collect the medium containing virus (P3) from shaker flasks.
Centrifuge the virus-containing medium at 500 g for 5 min at 4°C to remove cells and large debris. Store the supernatant at 4°C in dark for immediate use or at −20°C in dark for long-term use.
Protein expression.
Seed Hi-5 insect cells with viability of more than 95% into 1 L shake flask containing 300 mL ESf 921 Insect Cell Culture Medium at a density of 2 × 106 cells/mL.
Add P3 viral stock (1% v/v) to suspension Hi-5 cells.
Incubate the cells in a 27°C incubator with a stirring rate of 120 rpm.
At 48 h post infection, count and record cell density and viability.
Collect the cells by centrifuging the culture at 500 g for 10 min at 4°C to remove supernatant.
Store the cell pellet at −80°C for one year.
Pause point: The pellet can be stored at −80°C for one year but prolonged storage is not preferred for purification.
Protein purification
Timing: 2 days (for step 12)
This section describes the purification procedures of recombinant CPP-BoNTA proteins. Ni-NTA affinity chromatography and size exclusion chromatography (SEC) are involved. Either manual or automatic purification can be performed.
Purification with Ni-NTA agarose beads.

Resuspend cell pellet in 50–100 mL Ni-Lysis buffer, followed by homogenization by sonication with the settings of 70% power and two cycles of 5 min treatment with 5 s on/5 s off interval.
Centrifuge the sonicated cells at 16,000 g for 30 min at 4°C.
Note: If the centrifuged solution is not clear, transfer the supernatant to a new tube and repeat the centrifugation step.
Transfer the supernatant to a new tube. Add 2 mL Ni-NTA agarose beads (50% slurry; 1 mL settled volume) and rotate at 4°C for 1–3 h.
Note: Before mixing the Ni-NTA agarose beads with cell lysates, equilibrate the beads with 5 column volume (CV) of Ni-Lysis buffer.
Transfer the Ni-NTA agarose beads into column and wash with 50 mL Ni-Wash buffer I.
Wash the beads with 50 mL Ni-Wash buffer II. Concentrate the flow through to about 3 mL using 50 MWCO spin concentrator at 4°C.
Wash the beads with 50 mL Ni-Wash buffer III. Concentrate the flow through to about 3 mL using 50 MWCO spin concentrator at 4°C.
Elution with 50 mL Ni-elution buffer. Concentrate the elute to about 3 mL using 50 MWCO spin concentrator at 4°C.
Purification with SEC columns.
Equilibrate Superdex 200 resins in 10/300 GL column with 1.5 CV SEC buffer.
Load 500 μL eluted sample onto Superdex 200 in 10/300 GL column.
Harvest the target proteins according to the UV reads.
Store purified proteins at −80°C for one year.
Pause point: The protein samples can be stored at −80°C for one year but the activity should be carefully checked after prolonged storage.
In vitro characterization of CPP-BoNTA
Timing: 4 days

Before conducting analysis of the activity of CPP-BoNTA, the integrity and purity of the proteins should be evaluated. This section includes the procedures for three major steps: SDS-PAGE analyses, mass spectrometry analyses and in vitro cleavage assay.
Analysis of purity by SDS-PAGE
Timing: 1 day
SDS-PAGE analysis of purified CPP-BoNTA proteins.
Pull off the sticker from the GenScript pre-made gel and place the gel in the gel tank.
Transfer 1× MOPS SDS running buffer to the gel tank.
Remove the comb and load 10 μL of protein sample in each well.
Run the gel at 200 V for roughly 30 min.
Stain the gel with Coomassie blue staining buffer for 20 min.
Destain the gel with destaining buffer for roughly 40 min.
A representative result is shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Purified recombinant CPP-BoNTA fusion proteins
The molecular weight of each protein is indicated.
Note: This step is mainly used for analysis of the purity of the CPP-BoNTA proteins.
Analyses of molecular weight by mass spectrometry
Timing: 2 days
Note: Molecular weight is the primary parameter in the identification of peptides and proteins and can be determined by time of flight (TOF) mass spectrometry (MS). The principle of TOF is that ions will accelerate through the flight pipeline under the action of electric field, which will be then detected by the detector according to different flight time. The mass/charge ratio of ions (M/Z) is proportional to the flight time of ions.
Mass spectrometry analyses of CPP-BoNTA proteins (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. MS analysis of the molecular weight of CPP-BoNTA proteins
Prepare 10–50 μg of protein samples with a purity of more than 90%.

Use AB SCIEX TripleTOF™ 4600 coupled directly to a Nexera UHPLC LC-30A(SHIMADZU) with a 100 mm × 2.15 μm ACE C4 column for all LC-MS/MS analyses.
Set the mobile phase A to be H2O with 0.1 FA, the mobile phase B to be CH3CN with 0.1 FA, and the flow rate to be 0.4 mL/min.
Use Peakviewer software for database searching and spectral interpretation.
In vitro cleavage assay using SNAPtide
Timing: 1 day
Note: In the SNAPtide, the N-terminal fluorophore is fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) and C-terminal quencher is 4-((4-(dimethylamino) phenyl) azo) benzoic acid (DABCYL). Once cleaved, the peptide will release the fluorophore FITC, generating fluorescence signal that can be measured spectroscopically.
Evaluation of the in vitro activity of CPP-BoNTA proteins (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Evaluation of the in vitro activity of CPP-BoNTA proteins using SNAPtide assay
Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation (SD). The significant difference between commercially available BoNTA-LC and home-purified BoNTA proteins (BoNTA, T-BoNTA or Z-BoNTA) is analyzed using Student’s t test. The p values are indicated.
Prepare 96-well black microplate, and add reaction solution containing 1× SNAPtide assay buffer and 10 μM SNAPtide.
Add CPP-BoNTA proteins to the reaction to a final concentration of 100 nM in a 100 μL reaction solution.
Incubate the reaction at 37°C for 40 min.
Measure the fluorescence using a plate reader with an excitation wavelength of 490 nm and an emission wavelength of 523 nm.
In vitro analysis of the cell-penetrating activity of CPP-BoNTA in cell culture
Timing: 3 days
This section describes the procedures for analyzing the cell-penetrating activity of CPP-BoNTA in cell culture. Two major steps are involved including confocal imaging analysis and TissueFax cytometry-like analysis.
Analysis of treated N2a cells by confocal imaging
Timing: 2 days (for step 17)

This step describes how to analyze the cell-penetrating activity of CPP-BoNTA by immunofluorescence staining and confocal imaging in mouse neuroblastoma N2a cells (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Evaluation of the cell-penetrating activity of CPP-BoNTA proteins in N2a cells using immunofluorescence staining
Scale bar, 10 μm. The data in the bar plot are presented as mean ± SD. The significant differences between BoNTA and T-BoNTA or Z-BoNTA are analyzed using Student’s t test. The p values are indicated.
Mouse neuroblastoma N2a cells culture.
Maintain N2a cells in MEM EARLES supplemented with 10% FBS, 1% MEM NEAA and 100 U/mL penicillin/streptomycin at 37°C in fully humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2.
Coat 12 mm coverslips with 500 μL poly-L-lysine solution (1:10 dilution in water) by incubating at 25°C for 1 h in a 24-well plate.
Wash coverslips three times with sterile PBS and air dry at 4°C for 12–16 h.
Seed N2a cells on to poly-L-lysine-coated coverslips and culture in a 37°C/5% CO2 incubator for additional 2 days until a confluency of 70%–80% is reached.
After 4 h incubation with 100 nM CPP-BoNTA, fix N2a cells with 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) at 25°C for 15 min.
Permeabilization of N2a cells.
Treat cells with PBS containing 0.1% Triton X-100 for 10 min.
Wash cells three times with PBS containing 0.2% BSA.
Block non-specific binding site with PBS containing 0.2% BSA at 25°C for 30 min.
Primary antibody incubation.
Stain cells (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) with goat anti-FLAG (Novus) and rabbit anti-SV2A antibodies (Novus) at 1 to 200 dilution in PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Cover plate at 25°C for 1–2 h during incubation.
Wash the coverslips 5 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Wash the coverslips 5 times with PBS.
Wash the coverslips 5 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Secondary antibody incubation.

Stain cells (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA and incubate with Alexa568-conjugated donkey anti-rabbit IgG (Life/Invitrogen) and Alexa488-conjugated donkey anti-goat IgG (Life/ Invitrogen) secondary antibodies.
Cover plate at 25°C for 45 min during incubation.
Wash the coverslips 5 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Wash the coverslips 5 times with PBS.
Wash the coverslips 5 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Note: From this point on, the slices need to be kept in the dark. The slices can be stored at −80°C for three month.
Nuclei staining.
Stain antibody-labeled cells sections with Hoechst 33342 (Invitrogen) for nucleus visualization.
Cover plate at 25°C for 5–10 min during incubation.
Wash the coverslips 3 times with PBS.
Mounting.
Prepare microscope slides and add the coverslips on microscope slides with Prolong gold antifade reagent.
Leave the microscope slides at 25°C to dry in the dark for 12–16 h.
Store at 4°C for long-term use.
Confocal microscopy imaging.
Visualize samples on a LSM710 laser scanning confocal microscopy (Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH, Jena, Germany) with the excitation/emission filters for red and green channels to be 493 nm/598 nm and 410 nm/507 nm respectively.
Measure the fluorescence intensity in each cell using ZEN 2011 imaging software (Zeiss).
Note: Image analysis is carried out using the program FIJI. Background signal is subtracted from images using the Math function on the FIJI software.
TissueFAXS cytometry analysis
Timing: 1 day (for step 26)
This step describes the procedures for flow cytometry-like epifluorescence analysis using The TissueFAXS system. This approach is useful for quantification of a large set of samples.
Visualize the prepared samples from step 23 on TissueFAXS (TissueGnostics, Vienna, Austria) fluorescence imaging system. Scan the whole section slices and calculate the fluorescence intensity using TissueQuest software (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig7.jpg

Figure 7. TissueFAXS cytometry analysis of co-expression of BoNTA proteins with SV2 receptors in mouse N2a cells
In vivo analysis of the efficacy and cell-penetrating activity of CPP-BoNTA in mice
Timing: 7 days
This section describes the procedures for the in vivo analyses of CPP-BoNTA in mice. Two major steps are included: analysis of the efficacy of CPP-BoNTA using digit abduction score, and analysis the cell-penetrating in gastrocnemius muscle.
Digit abduction score (DAS) assay
Timing: 4 days (for step 27)
In this step, we use digit abduction score (DAS) assay, which measures muscle-weakening effectiveness,9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] to determine the pharmacologic activity (ED50) of BoNTA proteins. Therapeutic index is calculated using the determined ED50 and systemic toxicity (LD50).
Injection procedure (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Injection of BoNTA proteins into the right gastrocnemius muscle of mice
Prepare 8 to 12-week-old male or female C57BL/6 mice for intramuscular injection. For each experiment, inject at least five mice per dose (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_2356_12.csv
Dispense different doses of CPP-BoNTA according to the body weight of the mice, so that the mice of each doses receive a fixed volume of 5 μL.
Attach a 30-gauge needle to a sterile 250 μL Hamilton syringe.
Inject CPP-BoNTA or vehicle (0.9% saline) into the head of the right gastrocnemius muscle of mice.
Note: It is preferred to include 5 or more mice for each dose to make the results more reliable.
Critical: Due to the small hind limbs of mice, it is necessary to avoid the needle to pass through the gastrocnemius muscle, which will result in ineffective injection.

Critical: It is necessary to avoid bleeding during the injection, otherwise the mice may lick the wounds and swallow the injected proteins. If bleeding is caused, push the wound with an alcohol cotton ball to stop the bleeding and then wipe off the blood.
Measurement of DAS score.
At two days after injection, determine the DAS of each mouse.
Suspend mice briefly by their tails to elicit a characteristic startle response in which the mice extend their hind-limbs and abduct their hind digits.
Observe and record the shape of the foot and digits of the suspended mouse. The DAS values are assigned as follows9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]):
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Representative DAS values
The figure shows the various degree of digit abduction shown by mice.
Zero-point: flat foot, digit spread same as the untreated leg.
One-point: flat foot, a difference in the width of digit abduction compared to the untreated leg or two digits touching and the rest spread completely.
Two-point: flat foot, slight space open at tips of all digits or three digits touching.
Three-point: five digits touching if foot is flat, or four digits touching if foot is curved.
Four-point: curved foot, all five digits touching.
The doses and DAS results of BoNTA, T-BoNTA and Z-BoNTA proteins are summarized in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
Critical: Two observers are required for DAS measurements to ensure that the data obtained are unbiased. The two observers must be blinded to the treatment, and at no time should they communicate with regard to the DAS values that they assign.
Note: Data are shown as mean ± standard deviation (SD).
Determination of the systemic effects and therapeutic index.
Determine the half intramuscular lethal dose (IMLD50).

Note: IMLD50 is defined as the dose at which half of the mice die following treatment. Set the end point of monitoring at day 5, after which no further death can be found (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. The therapeutic index of BoNTA proteins
(A) Dose-dependent acute toxicity of BoNTA proteins. IM, intramuscular.
(B) Dose-dependent muscle-paralyzing activity of BoNTA proteins.
(C) The therapeutic index of BoNTA proteins.
Determine the half intramuscular effective dose (IMED50) (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9] and 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B).
Calculate the intramuscular therapeutic index by dividing IMLD50 by IMED50 (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C).
Immunofluorescence analysis of treated gastrocnemius muscle
Timing: 3 days (for step 30)
In this step, the mice injected with CPP-BoNTA in the previous experiment will be sacrificed and the gastrocnemius muscle tissue is collected and immunofluorescence stained for evaluation of the cell-penetrating activity of CPP-BoNTA in vivo.
Sample Preparation.
Section fresh gastrocnemius muscles into small pieces.
Fix immediately with 4% paraformaldehyde at 25°C for 10 min.
Dehydrate for 12–16 h in 30% sucrose.
Dry the tissue blocks with paper towels.
Place the tissue blocks on tissue molds.
Incubate the tissue blocks with 100% optimal cutting temperature compound (OCT) over a total period of 4 h at −80°C.
Frozen-section OCT-embedded gastrocnemius muscles serially at 10 μm interval along the transverse and longitudinal direction.
Blocking step.
Block non-specific binding site with PBS supplemented with 5% BSA at 25°C for 1 h.
Wash the sections 5 times with PBS for 5 min each time.
Primary antibody incubation.
Incubate the slices with goat anti-FLAG antibody and anti-SV2A antibodies which are diluted 200-fold in PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA at 4°C for 12–16 h.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.

Secondary antibody incubation.
Incubate with fluorochrome-conjugated secondary antibody which is diluted 1000-fold in PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA for 1 h at 25°C in dark.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS supplemented with 0.2% BSA.
Note: From this point on, the slices need to be kept in the dark.
Nucleus Staining.
Incubate with Hoechst 33342 which is diluted 5,000-fold in PBS for 10 min at 25°C in the dark.
Wash the slices 3 times with PBS.
Mounting.
Prepare microscope slides and add the coverslips on microscope slides with Prolong gold antifade reagent.
Coat the edges of the coverslip with a thin layer of clear nail polish and leave to dry in the dark for 12–16 h.
Store at 4°C for long-term use.
Pause point: The slides can be stored at 4°C for up to three months but prolonged storage may affect imaging resolution.
Confocal microscopy imaging.
Prepare microscope slides and add the coverslips on microscope slides with Prolong gold antifade reagent.
Visualize the samples on a LSM710 laser scanning confocal microscopy (Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH, Jena, Germany), with the excitation/emission filters for red and green channels to be 493 nm/598 nm and 410 nm/507 nm respectively.
Measure the fluorescence intensity in each cell by ZEN 2011 imaging software (Zeiss) (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2356-Fig11.jpg
Figure 11. Evaluation of the in vivo cellular uptake of intramuscularly injected CPP-BoNTA proteins in mouse gastrocnemius muscles using immunofluorescence staining
Scale bar, 200 μm. The data in the bar plot are presented as mean ± SD. The significant differences between BoNTA and T-BoNTA or Z-BoNTA are analyzed using Student’s t test. The p values are indicated.
